title: 114_hr2621
content:
The Act may be cited as the "China Human Rights Protection Act of 2015" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act, known as the "China Human Rights Protection Act of 2015," defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees" and "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights," which includes extrajudicial killings. The Act defines "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" to include extrajudicial killings, torture, prolonged arbitrary detention, forced abortion, organ harvesting without consent, and other denials of life, liberty, or security. A "United States person" refers to a US citizen or lawful permanent resident. The curr_chunk states that an entity can be admitted for permanent residence in the United States if it is organized under US laws or laws of any jurisdiction within the US, including foreign branches. The curr_chunk authorizes sanctions for gross violations of internationally recognized human rights. The President shall impose sanctions on individuals from China responsible for gross human rights violations, particularly against those advocating for freedoms like religion and expression. Sanctions may include ineligibility for a U.S. visa or admission, and property blocking for individuals from China involved in human rights violations. The President has the authority to block all transactions and property of individuals involved in human rights violations from China, in accordance with the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The President has the authority to issue regulations, licenses, and orders necessary to carry out the section related to blocking transactions and property of individuals involved in human rights violations from China. SEC. 4. WAIVER AUTHORITY AND EXCEPTION TO COMPLY WITH UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS AGREEMENT. The President has the authority to waive sanctions on individuals from China if it is in the national security interests of the United States. Sanctions do not apply if admitting the individual is necessary to comply with the United Nations Headquarters Agreement. The Headquarters Agreement was signed in 1947 between the United Nations and the United States, or other international obligations of the United States. SEC. 5. TERMINATION OF SANCTIONS.

The President can lift sanctions on a Chinese national if they didn't engage in sanctioned activities, were prosecuted, or show a change in behavior. 

SEC. 6. ESTABLISHMENT OF CHINA HUMAN RIGHTS DOCUMENTATION CENTER. The Secretary of State will establish the China Human Rights Documentation Center to compile evidence of human rights violations in China and create a searchable database for research and educational purposes. The China Human Rights Documentation Center will compile and publish evidence of human rights violations in China, including censorship, threats, surveillance, and detention of individuals. Lawyers representing clients detained in extra-legal centers, individuals detained arbitrarily in China (including Tibetans, Uyghurs, and Falun Gong members), democracy, labor, environmental, and free speech advocates, petitioners, bloggers, individuals targeted in anti-corruption campaigns, and members of independent religious communities are all supported by the China Human Rights Documentation Center. The China Human Rights Documentation Center supports individuals detained arbitrarily in China, including Tibetans, Uyghurs, and Falun Gong members, as well as democracy, labor, environmental, and free speech advocates, petitioners, bloggers, and members of independent religious communities. They highlight restrictions on freedom of religion, including arrests of religious leaders and coercive population control policies. The curr_chunk discusses various forms of exploitation and human rights violations, including threats to employment and residency, profiting from slave labor and trafficking, selling organs without consent, and disrupting trade unions. The curr_chunk authorizes funds for the Department of State to address human rights violations, including arbitrary detention as determined by the United Nations Working Group. The President is also granted regulatory authority to issue necessary regulations. SEC. 7. USE OF CREDIBLE EVIDENCE FOR SANCTIONS DETERMINATIONS AND REPORTS. The President should use credible evidence from various sources for imposing sanctions and reporting to Congress. This includes evidence from the China Human Rights Documentation Center, Department of State, other federal agencies, and congressional committees. The President must annually submit a report to Congress listing Chinese nationals sanctioned, describing the sanctions, and providing reasons for imposing or terminating them. The President must submit reports to Congress listing Chinese nationals sanctioned, describing the sanctions, and efforts to encourage other countries to impose similar sanctions. Initial report due within 180 days of enactment, subsequent reports on December 10 annually. The President must submit reports to Congress listing Chinese nationals sanctioned, describing the sanctions, and efforts to encourage other countries to impose similar sanctions. Reports are due annually on December 10, recognized as "Human Rights Day" since 1950. The report required by subsection (a) must be submitted in unclassified form, with the option to include a classified annex for individuals from China under sanctions if deemed vital for national security interests. The unclassified portion of the report must be made public. The unclassified portion of the report required by subsection (a) must be made public, including through publication in the Federal Register. The President is required to publish the list without regard to confidentiality requirements for visa records. SEC. 9. REPORT BY COMPTROLLER GENERAL TO CONGRESS ON IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS ACT. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within a year after the initial report, detailing the process to determine if a Chinese national has engaged in sanctioned activities and whether sanctions should be imposed. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress assessing the implementation of the Act and consulting with congressional committees and organizations.
